hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of a linked list. Each node has a value and a pointer to the next node. You will need to traverse the list to access each pair of adjacent nodes.
Remember how to calculate the greatest common divisor (GCD) of two numbers. You can use the Euclidean algorithm, which is efficient and straightforward.
Consider how you will insert new nodes into the linked list. You can't just replace existing nodes; you'll need to create new nodes and adjust pointers accordingly.
Think about edge cases. What happens if the linked list has only one node? In this case, you won't need to insert any new nodes.
As you traverse the list, you will need to keep track of the current node and the next node. After calculating the GCD, you will create a new node and link it appropriately.
When inserting a new node, ensure that the new node's next pointer points to the next node in the original list, and the current node's next pointer points to the new node.
You will need a loop to go through the list until you reach the end. Inside the loop, after inserting a new node, make sure to move the current pointer to the next node (which you just inserted).
Keep in mind the constraints provided in the problem. The maximum number of nodes is 5000, and the values are between 1 and 1000. Your solution should handle these efficiently.
Consider how you will return the modified linked list. You should return the head of the list, which remains unchanged, but now points to a more complex structure.

Finally, think about how to implement the GCD function and integrate it into your main logic. You can use a helper function to keep your code organized, but make sure to call it correctly within your loop.

questionNotes: Constraints: The number of nodes in the list is in the range [1, 5000].
Node values are guaranteed to be in the range [1, 1000].
If the list has only one node, return the original list as there are no pairs to insert GCDs for.
Return the head of the modified linked list after all insertions.
